task: The user has been unable to send MMS messages using their messaging app for the past few hours. Customer name: John Smith, phone number: 555-123-2002, current location: at home in the United States. They will consider the issue resolved when an MMS message can be successfully sent.

messages.content: Hi there! I‚Äôve been having trouble sending MMS messages from my phone today‚Äîthey just won't go through. Could you help me figure out what‚Äôs going on?

I can help with that. First, I need to identify your account to check your line settings. Could you please share one of the following:
- The phone number on the line that‚Äôs having the MMS issue
- Your customer ID
- Your full name and date of birth (YYYY-MM-DD)

Once I have that, I‚Äôll guide you through quick checks for:
- Whether cellular service and mobile data are working (MMS requires both)
- Network settings (APN/MMSC, network mode)
- Data roaming status (if you‚Äôre traveling)
- Messaging app permissions
- Wi-Fi Calling interference

If you‚Äôd like to start while you grab that info, here are two quick checks you can do now:
1) Check your phone‚Äôs status bar and tell me what you see for signal strength, network type (5G/4G/3G/2G), and whether mobile data is enabled.
2) Try browsing a website using mobile data (with Wi-Fi turned off) and let me know if it loads.
messages.reasoning_content: Plan: Start MMS troubleshooting by verifying basic connectivity first. Need to identify customer via phone lookup. Then guide through checks: cellular service status, mobile data status, APN settings (MMSC), network mode (not 2G), Wi-Fi Calling interference, and messaging app permissions. Use diagnostic tools stepwise and apply fix actions as indicated. Keep concise, follow tech_support_policy sequence.

messages.content: Status Bar: üìµ No Signal | üìµ Data Disabled | üîã 80%

Thanks! I‚Äôll provide my details‚Äîmy name is John Smith, and the phone number on this line is 555-123-2002.

For the first quick check: Right now my phone‚Äôs status bar shows no signal and that mobile data is disabled.

Could you let me know what I should try next?

Thanks for the details, John. Since you‚Äôre seeing no signal and mobile data is disabled, let‚Äôs start with the basics to restore service and then re-enable mobile data. Please try these steps in order and tell me what happens after each:

Step 1: Turn on Mobile Data
- Go to Settings > Network & Internet > Mobile data and toggle it ON.
- If you can‚Äôt find it, swipe down from the top and look for a ‚ÄúMobile data‚Äù toggle in the quick settings panel.

Step 2: Check Airplane Mode
- If you see an airplane icon in the status bar, Airplane Mode is ON.
- Turn it OFF: swipe down to quick settings and tap the Airplane Mode icon.
- After turning it OFF, wait 10‚Äì15 seconds and see if signal returns.

Step 3: Reboot the device
- Restart your phone. This can clear temporary glitches affecting the radio.
- After reboot, check if the signal returns and whether mobile data shows as enabled.

Step 4: Check the SIM
- If you still have no signal:
  - Power off the phone.
  - Remove the SIM card, wait 10 seconds, then reinsert it firmly.
  - Power the phone back on and wait for it to register on the network.

Step 5: Check network mode preference
- Go to Settings > Network & Internet > Mobile network > Preferred network type.
- Ensure it‚Äôs not set to 2G only. Set it to a mode that includes 3G/4G/5G (e.g., ‚Äú4G/5G Auto‚Äù or similar).

What to report back:
- After Step 1: Did the mobile data toggle turn on successfully?
- After Step 2: Did the airplane icon disappear?
- After Step 3: Do you see signal bars again? If yes, does the network type show (5G/4G/LTE)?
- After Step 4: Any change?
- After Step 5: What network type is selected now?

If signal returns and mobile data is on, try sending an MMS. If it still fails, we‚Äôll check APN settings and app permissions.

If none of these steps bring back signal, I can also look up your account using the phone number 555-123-2002, but I‚Äôll need your date of birth for verification. Would you like me to do that after we try these steps?
messages.reasoning_content: User reports no signal and mobile data disabled. Likely Airplane Mode or SIM issue. Provide step-by-step tech support actions to turn on mobile data, check/turn off Airplane Mode, reseat SIM, then check APN and network mode. Ask for DOB for verification if further account checks are needed.

messages.content:
Mobile Data is now ON.
Status Bar: üìµ No Signal | üìµ Data Disabled | üîã 80%

I went ahead and turned mobile data ON, but my status bar still shows no signal and data as disabled. Should I move on to the next step with Airplane Mode, or do you want to check something else first?

Yes, let‚Äôs proceed to the next step with Airplane Mode. Please:

1) Turn Airplane Mode ON, wait 5 seconds, then turn it OFF.
2) Give it about 10‚Äì15 seconds to reconnect and check if signal bars appear and whether mobile data now shows as enabled.

If there‚Äôs still no signal after that, please reboot the device next, and if needed, reseat the SIM. If you prefer, I can also pull up your account now‚Äîjust share your date of birth for verification so I can check line status and settings from our side.
messages.reasoning_content: Guide the user to proceed to Airplane Mode toggle next, then reboot if needed. Offer to check SIM status and proceed to reseat SIM if still no signal. Request date of birth to verify account if needed. Avoid making any tool calls until identity verified.

messages.content:

I've just turned Airplane Mode ON. Should I wait five seconds and turn it OFF now?

Yes, please turn Airplane Mode OFF now. After you do that, wait about 10‚Äì15 seconds and then check:
- Do signal bars appear in the status bar?
- Does mobile data show as enabled?

Let me know what you see, and we‚Äôll decide the next step.
messages.reasoning_content: Guide the user to turn Airplane Mode OFF after 5 seconds, wait 10‚Äì15 seconds, then recheck signal and mobile data. If still no signal, proceed to reboot and then reseat SIM.

messages.content:
Airplane Mode is now OFF.
Status Bar: üìµ No Signal | üìµ Data Disabled | üîã 80%
I‚Äôve turned Airplane Mode OFF and waited about 15 seconds, but I still see no signal and mobile data is disabled in the status bar. What should I try next?

Next, please reboot the device:
- Hold the power button, select Restart (or Power off, then power it back on after 10 seconds).
- After the phone comes back up, wait 10‚Äì15 seconds and check again:
  - Do signal bars appear?
  - Does mobile data show as enabled?

If there‚Äôs still no signal, we‚Äôll reseat the SIM next. If you‚Äôd like me to check your account for line issues in parallel, please share your date of birth so I can verify and look up 555-123-2002.
messages.reasoning_content: Provide next concrete step: reboot the device. Ask for results afterward. If still no signal, plan is to reseat SIM and potentially lookup account with DOB to verify line status and suspension.

messages.content:
Restarting network services...
Status Bar: üìµ No Signal | üìµ Data Disabled | üîã 80%

I've rebooted the device and waited, but there's still no signal and mobile data remains disabled. This is starting to get a bit frustrating since nothing has changed yet. Should I go ahead and try reseating the SIM card now, or do you want to check my account from your side as well?

Let‚Äôs do both: please reseat the SIM now, and I can start checking your account as soon as you share your date of birth for verification.

To reseat the SIM:
- Power off the phone.
- Remove the SIM card, wait about 10 seconds, then reinsert it firmly.
- Power the phone back on and wait 10‚Äì15 seconds.
- Check for signal bars and whether mobile data shows as enabled.

While you do that, could you provide your date of birth (YYYY-MM-DD)? With that, I can look up the account for line 555-123-2002 to see if there are any line suspensions or provisioning issues that might be causing the no‚Äësignal condition.
messages.reasoning_content: We should both reseat the SIM and start account lookup. We need DOB for verification. We'll ask the user to reseat SIM now and request DOB so we can pull the account and check line status, suspension, contract, roaming, and possibly look up customer by phone.

messages.content:
SIM card re-seated successfully.
Status Bar: üì∂¬π Poor | 2G | üì± Data Enabled | üîã 80%
I‚Äôve reseated the SIM card as you suggested. Now the status bar shows one bar of signal (poor), 2G network, and mobile data is enabled. What should I do next?

Great progress‚Äîsignal is back. Since you‚Äôre on 2G and MMS generally needs at least a 3G connection, let‚Äôs improve the network mode:

Step 1: Change network mode
- Go to Settings > Network & Internet > Mobile network > Preferred network type.
- Select a mode that includes 3G, 4G, or 5G (e.g., ‚Äú4G/5G Auto,‚Äù ‚Äú4G/5G Preferred,‚Äù or ‚Äú4G/3G/2G Auto‚Äù).
- Wait 30 seconds and check the status bar. Ideally it should now show 3G, 4G/LTE, or 5G.

Step 2: Reconnect mobile data if needed
- If mobile data turned off during the network change, toggle it back ON.

Step 3: Test MMS
- Try sending a picture message to a contact.

If it still fails:
- We‚Äôll check APN settings next and make sure the MMSC URL is present.
- We‚Äôll verify messaging app has the necessary permissions.
- We may also briefly toggle Wi-Fi Calling OFF if it‚Äôs on, since it can sometimes interfere with MMS.

Please tell me what network type you see after Step 1 and whether the test MMS sends successfully.
messages.reasoning_content: Signal returned at 2G with mobile data enabled. Next: upgrade network mode to 4G/5G preferred so MMS can work, then retest MMS. If still failing, we‚Äôll check APN/MMSC and messaging app permissions, then reboot if APN reset is needed.

messages.content:
Preferred Network Mode set to: 4g_5g_preferred
Status Bar: üì∂‚Å¥ Excellent | 5G | üì± Data Enabled | üîã 80%
Your messaging app cannot send MMS messages.

I changed my network mode to 4G/5G preferred. Now the status bar shows excellent signal strength, 5G network, and mobile data is enabled.

However, when I just tried to send an MMS, it still wouldn‚Äôt go through. What‚Äôs the next thing you‚Äôd like me to try?

Excellent‚Äîsignal and data look good. The next likely cause is APN/MMSC settings, messaging app permissions, or Wi‚ÄëFi Calling interference. Let‚Äôs check these one by one:

1) Check APN/MMSC
- Go to Settings > Mobile network > Access Point Names (APN) or similar.
- Make sure there‚Äôs an active carrier APN selected, and that it includes an MMSC URL (often labeled MMSC or MMS proxy).
- If you see multiple APNs or none selected, tap to select the carrier one.
- If MMSC is missing or looks incorrect, reset to default:
  - Use ‚ÄúReset to default‚Äù in the APN menu (or delete and readd the carrier APN if needed).
  - After resetting, reboot the phone.

2) Check messaging app permissions
- Go to Settings > Apps > Messaging (or your messaging app‚Äôs name).
- Open Permissions and ensure Storage and SMS (or Messages) are allowed.
- If either is denied, grant them.

3) Check Wi‚ÄëFi Calling
- Go to Settings > Calls (or Mobile network) > Wi‚ÄëFi Calling.
- If it‚Äôs ON, toggle it OFF, then try sending an MMS.
- You can turn it back on later if you rely on it.

4) Try sending an MMS again after these steps
- Please turn Wi‚ÄëFi off during the test to ensure it uses mobile data.

Let me know:
- Does the APN show an MMSC URL?
- Are Storage and SMS permissions granted for the messaging app?
- Is Wi‚ÄëFi Calling currently on or off?
- Does the MMS send after these changes?

If you prefer, I can also pull up your account to verify line provisioning. To do that, I just need your date of birth (YYYY-MM-DD) for verification.
messages.reasoning_content: User has 5G signal and mobile data enabled but MMS still fails. Next per policy: check APN/MMSC, then messaging app permissions, then Wi-Fi Calling interference. Ask user to run can_send_mms, check_apn_settings, check_app_permissions(messaging), check_wifi_calling_status. If APN incorrect or MMSC missing, reset APN and reboot. If Wi-Fi Calling ON, toggle OFF. If permissions missing, grant storage and SMS. Since we can't run those tools here, provide step-by-step instructions to access these settings on the phone, or ask the user to share the outputs of those checks if available.

messages.content:
Current APN Name: internet
MMSC URL (for picture messages): Not Set
(These are technical settings, usually best left unchanged.)
I checked my APN settings: the current APN name is "internet," but there‚Äôs no MMSC URL set. Does this mean I should reset my APN settings to default or manually add the MMSC URL next?

Yes‚Äîwithout an MMSC URL, MMS won‚Äôt work. Please reset your APN settings to default:

1) Reset APN
- Go to Settings > Mobile network > Access Point Names (APN).
- Tap the menu (three dots) and choose Reset to default (or Restore defaults).
- Confirm when prompted.

2) Reboot the phone
- Restart your device after the reset so the changes take full effect.

3) Verify and test
- After reboot, re-check the APN list: the correct carrier APN should be selected and include an MMSC URL.
- Turn Wi‚ÄëFi off, ensure mobile data is on, and try sending an MMS.

If the MMS still fails after the reset and reboot:
- Check messaging app permissions (Storage and SMS).
- Temporarily turn Wi‚ÄëFi Calling OFF and try again.

Would you like me to look up your account as well to confirm there are no provisioning issues? If so, please provide your date of birth for verification.
messages.reasoning_content: User reports APN lacks MMSC. Per policy, guide to reset APN to default and reboot. After that, test MMS. If still fails, check messaging app permissions and Wi-Fi Calling. Offer to pull up account if needed with DOB verification.

I reset my APN settings to default and rebooted the device. After checking, the APN now shows an MMSC URL ("http://mms.carrier.com/mms/wapenc"). Mobile data is still ON, and I tried sending an MMS, but it still won‚Äôt go through.

Should I check the messaging app permissions next, or would you like me to do something else?

Let‚Äôs check the messaging app permissions next, then try one more quick configuration:

1) Check messaging app permissions
- Go to Settings > Apps > Messaging (or your messaging app‚Äôs name).
- Open Permissions and confirm that Storage and SMS (or Messages) are allowed.
- If either is denied or not granted, grant them.

2) Turn Wi‚ÄëFi Calling OFF temporarily
- Go to Settings > Calls (or Mobile network) > Wi‚ÄëFi Calling.
- If ON, toggle it OFF.
- Try sending an MMS with Wi‚ÄëFi off.

3) If it still fails, do a quick MMS readiness check on the phone
- Try a smaller photo (under 1 MB) if possible.
- Also, ensure mobile data is on and that you have at least some signal.
- If you can, try sending to a different contact.

Please let me know:
- Are Storage and SMS permissions granted for the messaging app?
- Is Wi‚ÄëFi Calling now off?
- Does the MMS go through after these changes?

If it still doesn‚Äôt work, I can look up your account for any provisioning issues. I‚Äôll just need your date of birth (YYYY-MM-DD) to verify.
messages.reasoning_content: Proceed to check messaging app permissions, then Wi‚ÄëFi Calling, then simple MMS capability test. If still failing, request DOB to run account checks or proceed with MMS test tool.

I tried sending an MMS again, but it still won‚Äôt go through. Anything else I should check, or would you like to look up my account provisioning next?

Thanks for checking those. Since the basics are in place and MMS still isn‚Äôt working, let‚Äôs look up your account to check for provisioning issues (for example, whether your line is flagged correctly for MMS or if there‚Äôs any restriction).
